titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Harold I. Seeley, Jr. Collection on Cherry Grove
Seeley (Harold I., Jr.) Collection on Cherry Grove
titlestmt.author: compiled by Christine Connolly, Carol King, and Claryn Spies

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 1, 2019 at 08:05

did.unittitle: Harold I. Seeley, Jr. collection on Cherry Grove

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The materials comprise correspondence, meeting minutes, reports, printed ephemera, posters, photographs, and play scripts collected by Harold I. Seeley, Jr. that document the activities of the Arts Project of Cherry Grove, as well as the community of Cherry Grove, a lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) resort community on Fire Island, off the coast of Long Island, New York.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Harold I. Seeley, Jr., 2008-2009.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Harold I. Seeley, Jr. Collection on Cherry Grove (MS 1908). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Harold I. Seeley, Jr. had been a volunteer for Cherry Grove Arts Project activities since his arrival at Cherry Grove in the mid 1970s, donating his time as board member, set designer, and performer. In 1982, Seeley founded the Cherry Grove Archives, collecting materials to preserve the history of the Cherry Grove community and the arts project. He died in Brooklyn, New York, on January 7, 2012.

The Arts Project Cherry Grove (APCG) was founded in 1948 as a non-profit community service organization providing an environment receptive to showcasing various art forms. Its fundraising events include art shows; theater productions; casino and bingo nights; concerts; socials; balls; and membership parties. Monies raised benefit various organizations of Cherry Grove, a hamlet located on Fire Island, New York, and reputedly the nation's first lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender/transsexual (LGBT) community.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials comprise correspondence, meeting minutes, reports, printed ephemera, posters, photographs, and play scripts collected by Harold I. Seeley, Jr. that document the activities of the Arts Project of Cherry Grove, as well as the community of Cherry Grove, a lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) resort community on Fire Island, off the coast of Long Island, New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials in this accession were taken from both the Cherry Grove Archives and the personal collection of the donor. The materials comprise meeting minutes, reports, printed ephemera, clippings, and photographs that document the activities of the Arts Project of Cherry Grove, as well as the community of Cherry Grove.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arrangement of the materials preserves the distinction between those coming from the Cherry Grove Archives and those coming from Harold Seeley's personal collection. Therein, files are arranged topically, primarily by names of organizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession comprises records of the Arts Project of Cherry Grove (APCG) as well as materials related to the greater Cherry Grove community. Records from APCG include financial records, assistant books and records, and general administrative and project files. Assistant books and records contain board meeting minutes, board meeting agendas, contact information for the Board of Directors, and notes on projects in progress. Financial records include treasurer reports, budgets, and ledger pages. Other records include ephemera from APCG events such as fliers and play programs, correspondence, and files related to specific projects. Materials related to the Cherry Grove community at large include correspondence and documents from other Cherry Grove community organizations, guidebooks to Fire Island, photographs, and newspaper clippings. Materials date from 1924 to 2011, with the bulk from 1951 to the mid-2000s.
